clinicalPearls: Full stomach precautions - modified RSI with gentle mask ventilation
Correct electrolytes before induction (K+ was 3.2, corrected to 3.8)
Consider awake intubation if severely dehydrated
keyTakeaways: NG decompression essential before induction
Small doses of propofol adequate in dehydrated infants
wouldDoAgain: Same approach worked well
wouldChangePerspective: Consider remifentanil infusion instead of bolus fentanyl

clinicalPearls: Reduced local anesthetic dose due to age and positioning
Multimodal analgesia crucial for early mobilization
Consider holding metformin 48h postop due to CKD
keyTakeaways: Combined technique provides excellent analgesia with reduced opioid requirements
Spinal morphine provides 18-24h analgesia
wouldDoAgain: Same technique, excellent outcome
wouldChangePerspective: Add adductor canal block for better postop mobility

clinicalPearls: Co-load with crystalloid more effective than preload
Phenylephrine preferred over ephedrine for maternal hypotension
Early administration of uterotonic agents reduces blood loss
keyTakeaways: CSE provides flexibility for extended surgery if needed
Intrathecal morphine provides excellent postop analgesia
wouldDoAgain: Same technique, worked perfectly
wouldChangePerspective: Consider TAP blocks for additional analgesia

clinicalPearls: Lidocaine with propofol reduces injection pain
No muscle relaxant needed for short ENT cases
Maintain spontaneous ventilation throughout
keyTakeaways: Quick cases benefit from avoiding muscle relaxants
Sevoflurane only maintenance works well for BMT
wouldDoAgain: Same simple technique
wouldChangePerspective: Consider intranasal fentanyl preop for anxious children

clinicalPearls: Preoxygenation crucial - use CPAP if available
Video laryngoscopy first choice in obese patients
Multimodal analgesia essential to minimize opioids
Consider TAP blocks for bariatric surgery
keyTakeaways: ERAS protocol improves outcomes in bariatric surgery
Sugammadex ensures complete reversal in obese patients
Extubate awake, sitting up when possible
wouldDoAgain: Add bilateral TAP blocks
wouldChangePerspective: Use CPAP for preoxygenation from the start

complications.management: 20 minutes ACLS/BLS, intubation, epinephrine, bicarbonate, defibrillation
complications.outcome: ROSC achieved, patient survived neurologically intact

clinicalPearls: Undiagnosed OSA is a MAJOR risk factor - always screen thoroughly (STOP-BANG, neck circumference, partner history)
Combination of neuraxial block + sedation can be lethal in severe OSA patients
Supine positioning after spinal worsens airway obstruction in OSA
High CO2 (110!) suggests prolonged hypoventilation/obstruction before arrest
Consider awake positioning and minimal/no sedation for suspected OSA with neuraxial
ABG during arrest can guide resuscitation (severe respiratory vs metabolic acidosis)
keyTakeaways: OSA + Spinal + Sedation = Potential catastrophe
Even 'light' MAC sedation (50 mcg/kg/min propofol) can cause complete airway obstruction in severe OSA
Ask specifically: 'Has anyone told you that you stop breathing when you sleep?'
Consider STOP-BANG screening for ALL patients, regardless of body habitus
When spinal is working, sedation may be unnecessary - especially in high-risk patients
wouldDoAgain: Spinal WITHOUT sedation, maintain sitting position longer, or consider GA with secured airway
wouldChangePerspective: 1) More aggressive OSA screening preop 2) No sedation with neuraxial if any OSA suspicion 3) Consider awake fiberoptic if GA needed 4) If sedation required, use high-flow nasal cannula or CPAP

outcome.longTermOutcome: Full neurological recovery, eventual discharge home

differentialDiagnosis: Hypoxic respiratory arrest from OSA/airway obstruction (most likely)
Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (unlikely given timeline)

rootCauseAnalysis.primaryCause: Undiagnosed severe OSA with propofol-induced airway obstruction
systemIssues: Consider mandatory STOP-BANG for all patients
Develop protocol for suspected OSA + neuraxial anesthesia

comorbidities: Previous CVA with residual left weakness

procedure.name: Exploratory Laparotomy for Small Bowel Obstruction

anesthetic.emergence: Delayed extubation due to fluid overload

clinicalPearls: Severe AS: Maintain sinus rhythm, avoid tachycardia, maintain afterload, careful fluid balance
Etomidate preserves hemodynamics better than propofol in AS
Epidural can be used cautiously in AS - slow titration is key
Pre-induction arterial line essential for beat-to-beat monitoring
Have phenylephrine infusion ready BEFORE induction
Consider ICU bed availability before starting urgent cases in high-risk patients
INR >2.5 increases epidural hematoma risk - weigh risks/benefits
keyTakeaways: Fixed cardiac output states tolerate hemodynamic changes poorly
Neuraxial can work in AS if titrated slowly with vasopressor support
Multi-disciplinary planning improves outcomes (cards, ICU, surgery)
Sometimes 'urgent' can wait 6-12 hours for optimization
wouldDoAgain: Consider awake epidural placement first, then gentle GA induction
wouldChangePerspective: Push for preop echo and cardiology consult even in urgent cases - would have helped with fluid management. Consider PA catheter or FloTrac for goal-directed therapy
consultations: Cardiology: Recommended proceed with surgery, optimize volume status
ICU: Preop evaluation for postop bed
Cardiac surgery: On standby for emergency valve if needed

procedure.name: Emergency Craniotomy for SDH Evacuation + Exploratory Laparotomy
procedure.position: Supine → Left lateral for craniotomy → Supine for laparotomy

complications.management: Flooded field, aspiration via CVC, position change
Forced air warmer, fluid warmer, increased room temp

clinicalPearls: Full stomach + increased ICP = challenging RSI (no positive pressure but risk aspiration)
Ketamine safe in TBI when ventilation controlled - maintains CPP
Place arterial line and CVC before turning prone/lateral if possible
Permissive hypotension contraindicated in TBI - maintain CPP >60
Check pupils regularly during neurosurgery
1:1:1 massive transfusion protocol early in pediatric trauma
Warm everything - room, fluids, blood products (children cool quickly)
Consider PICU bed/resources BEFORE starting case
keyTakeaways: Competing priorities: Full stomach vs ICP vs hemorrhage control
Early blood products in pediatric trauma - don't wait for lab values
Maintain CPP >60 even during hemorrhage (use vasopressors)
Pediatric craniotomy positioning requires extreme care - short neck, large head
Two surgical teams require choreographed anesthetic management
wouldDoAgain: Place scalp block for reduced anesthetic requirements during neuromonitoring
wouldChangePerspective: Start blood products earlier - waited for labs initially. Consider ECMO standby for severe traumatic brain injury with hemodynamic instability

neuroMonitoring.mep: Not performed due to emergency nature

outcome.neurologicalOutcome: GCS 14 at discharge, mild cognitive deficits

teamCommunication: Trauma activation with anesthesia, neurosurgery, trauma surgery, blood bank, PICU
Timeouts for position changes and surgical team switches
Real-time communication about ICP and hemodynamics between teams

familyInteraction.preop: Brief discussion with parents, consent by two physicians
familyInteraction.postop: Detailed discussion with both surgical teams present

obstetricDetails.presentingSymptoms: Severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, absent fetal heart tones
obstetricDetails.fetalStatus: Intrauterine fetal demise confirmed by ultrasound

procedure.name: Emergency Cesarean Hysterectomy for Placental Abruption with DIC
procedure.position: Supine with left uterine displacement → Trendelenburg

maintenance: Converted to TIVA with propofol/ketamine due to uterine atony

complications.management: Massive transfusion protocol, factor VIIa as rescue
All uterotonic agents, B-Lynch suture failed, proceeded to hysterectomy

clinicalPearls: Placental abruption often presents with DIC - check coags ASAP but don't wait to start blood
Volatile anesthetics cause uterine relaxation - may need to convert to TIVA
4 Ts of PPH: Tone, Trauma, Tissue, Thrombin (coagulopathy)
Factor VIIa is rescue therapy only - fix other parameters first
Cell saver contraindicated with amniotic fluid exposure (AFE risk)
Keep patient warm - hypothermia worsens coagulopathy
Early hysterectomy decision saves lives - don't delay if uterotonics failing
Communicate frequently with OB about blood loss - surgical drapes hide volume
keyTakeaways: Obstetric hemorrhage requires IMMEDIATE aggressive resuscitation
Start MTP early - O-negative blood if type not available
Ketamine maintains hemodynamics better than propofol for induction
Two large bore IVs minimum, consider central access early
Point-of-care testing (TEG/ROTEM) guides targeted therapy
wouldDoAgain: Earlier activation of MTP, start with 4 units in room
wouldChangePerspective: Place arterial line before induction if time permits. Consider ECMO/bypass team backup for severe cases. Would use viscoelastic testing (TEG/ROTEM) to guide products

teamDynamics.personnel: 2 anesthesiologists, 2 OB surgeons, GYN-ONC backup, 4 nurses, 2 techs
teamDynamics.challenges: Initial underestimation of blood loss by surgical team

outcome.reproductiveOutcome: Hysterectomy - unable to have future pregnancies
outcome.psychosocial: PTSD requiring counseling for fetal loss and hysterectomy

debriefing.whatWentWell: Rapid team assembly, early MTP activation, good communication with blood bank
debriefing.improvements: Need better initial estimation of blood loss, earlier arterial line, consider pre-arrival blood preparation for suspected abruption
debriefing.systemChanges: Implemented abruption box with 4 units O-neg in L&D

comorbidities: Left frontal glioma near Broca's area

psychosocial.primaryConcern: Maintaining ability to speak and teach

procedure.name: Awake Craniotomy with Cortical Mapping for Tumor Resection
procedure.position: Lateral decubitus with head in pins

anesthetic.airway: Nasal airway → LMA Supreme → Natural airway → LMA Supreme
anesthetic.emergence: Gentle awakening in OR for neuro exam

complications.management: Cold saline irrigation, midazolam 1mg ready but not needed
Verbal reassurance, husband brought to OR, 0.5mg midazolam
Head up 30°, increased propofol, mild hyperventilation to PaCO2 32

intraoperativeMapping.motorMapping: Positive stimulation at 4mA - tumor margin adjusted

speechMapping.adjustments: Resection limited at posterior margin to preserve speech

clinicalPearls: Scalp block is ESSENTIAL - inadequate block leads to failure
Pin sites need separate infiltration - often forgotten
Dexmedetomidine provides anxiolysis without respiratory depression
Keep propofol <50 mcg/kg/min during speech testing to avoid dysarthria
Have midazolam drawn up for seizures but avoid if possible (clouds neuro exam)
Cold saline irrigation first-line for stimulation-induced seizures
Consider urinary catheter - long case and diuretics
Prepare family member for possible OR entry if patient anxious
Practice mapping tasks preoperatively when patient calm
keyTakeaways: Patient selection crucial - motivated, psychologically prepared patients do better
Preoperative rehearsal of intraoperative tasks improves cooperation
Smooth transitions between asleep-awake phases prevent patient distress
Communication with patient throughout - explain sounds, sensations
Having experienced neuroanesthesiologist improves success

psychologicalManagement.preoperative: Met patient 3 times, practiced tasks, tour of OR, anxiolytic premedication avoided
psychologicalManagement.intraoperative: Constant verbal contact, husband briefly in OR, positive reinforcement
psychologicalManagement.challenges: Claustrophobia under drapes, drilling noise, awareness of brain surgery
psychologicalManagement.techniques: Guided imagery, counting exercises, praise for cooperation

wouldDoAgain: Excellent tumor resection with preserved speech - same technique
wouldChangePerspective: Consider preoperative psychological preparation program for all awake craniotomies. Would use noise-canceling headphones during bone work. Consider virtual reality distraction during awake phase.

outcome.neurologicalOutcome: No speech deficits, gross total resection achieved
outcome.30dayOutcome: Returned to teaching, mild word-finding difficulty improving
outcome.tumorPathology: Grade II oligodendroglioma, IDH mutant, 1p/19q co-deleted

teamCommunication.timeout: Specific plan for each phase discussed
teamCommunication.signaling: Hand signals established for patient (1 finger = yes, 2 = no)
teamCommunication.emergencyPlan: Crash airway kit immediately available, difficult airway cart in room

postoperativeInterview.patientQuote: Scary but fascinating to be awake. The team's communication helped immensely.
postoperativeInterview.whatHelped: Husband's presence, constant communication, knowing what to expect
postoperativeInterview.suggestions: Music during non-testing periods, warmer blankets

comorbidities: End-stage liver disease - Hepatitis C cirrhosis

anhepatic.challenges: Loss of hepatic metabolism, severe acidosis, hypocalcemia
anhepatic.management: Continuous calcium infusion, bicarbonate, CRRT started

complications.management: Epinephrine, calcium, atropine, brief CPR (30 seconds)

complications.event: Massive bleeding from hepatic artery anastomosis

complications.management: Forced air warmer, fluid warmer, increased room temp

clinicalPearls: Avoid preop anxiolytics - hepatic encephalopathy risk
Large bore access essential - 9Fr introducer + multiple large PIVs
Keep CVP <5 during dissection to reduce bleeding
Anticipate reperfusion syndrome - have epinephrine drawn up
TEG guides blood products better than conventional coags
Citrate toxicity common - prophylactic calcium infusion
Consider CRRT early for acidosis, hyperkalemia, volume overload
Normothermia crucial for coagulation - aggressive warming
Post-reperfusion hyperglycemia common - check glucose frequently
Communication with surgical team about graft quality affects management
keyTakeaways: Three distinct phases require different management strategies
Reperfusion syndrome can be life-threatening - be prepared
Coagulopathy is multifactorial - treat all components
Metabolic derangements are expected - aggressive correction needed
Team coordination crucial - surgeon, anesthesia, perfusion, blood bank
wouldDoAgain: Consider VV bypass for severe hemodynamic instability during anhepatic phase
wouldChangePerspective: Start CRRT earlier in anhepatic phase. Consider using PCC instead of large volume FFP. Would place PAC for better cardiac output monitoring during reperfusion.

bloodBankCoordination.productsInRoom: 6 PRBCs, 6 FFP, 1 platelet, 2 cryo at start
bloodBankCoordination.specialRequests: Low titer O+ blood used initially

graftDetails.graftAppearance: Good initial perfusion, bile production at 3 hours

complications30day: Mild acute rejection POD 7 - treated with steroids

comorbidities: Coronary artery disease s/p stent 2 years ago

maintenance: Epidural infusion 0.1% bupivacaine with fentanyl 2mcg/mL at 6mL/hr
anesthetic.emergence: Deep extubation to single-lumen tube, then awake extubation

regionalDetails.technique: Loss of resistance to saline, sitting position

adjustments.intervention: Changed to pressure control 22cmH2O, added 5cm CPAP to operative lung

complications.management: CPAP to operative lung, recruitment, bronchoscopy to check position, intermittent two-lung ventilation
complications.outcome: Resolved, able to continue VATS approach

complications.management: Deepened anesthesia, albuterol MDI 8 puffs, IV lidocaine 50mg
Confirmed chest tube position, avoided positive pressure

clinicalPearls: Epidural before induction provides better hemodynamic stability
DLT sizing: Female 35-37Fr, Male 39-41Fr typically
Always confirm position with FOB after positioning and periodically during case
Pressure control often better than volume control for OLV in COPD
CPAP 5-10cm to operative lung before clamping PA improves oxygenation
Keep volatile <1 MAC to avoid inhibiting hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction
Permissive hypercapnia acceptable (PaCO2 up to 60-70) to avoid barotrauma
Consider bronchodilators prophylactically in COPD patients
Deep extubation to SLT reduces coughing/bucking on surgical repair
keyTakeaways: Poor PFTs don't contraindicate surgery but require meticulous planning
Multiple strategies needed for hypoxemia during OLV
Postop analgesia crucial for pulmonary recovery - epidural superior
Early mobilization prevents complications in high-risk patients
Have backup plan for conversion to open if VATS fails

postoperativeManagement.analgesiaRegimen: Epidural x3 days, transition to PO meds
postoperativeManagement.mobilization: Out of bed POD 0, ambulating POD 1
postoperativeManagement.pulmonaryToilet: IS q1h while awake, chest PT BID
postoperativeManagement.disposition: Floor bed with continuous pulse oximetry

wouldDoAgain: Excellent pain control with epidural, avoided ICU admission
wouldChangePerspective: Consider serratus anterior block as backup to epidural. Would use higher CPAP (10cm) earlier to operative lung. Consider IV lidocaine infusion for COPD patients.

cardiacHistory.diagnosis: HLHS with mitral atresia, aortic atresia
surgeries: Norwood with Sano shunt - day 5 of life
cardiacHistory.lastEcho: Moderate RV function, moderate TR, patent fenestration

principles: Passive pulmonary blood flow - no subpulmonary ventricle
Systemic venous pressure drives pulmonary circulation
Afterload sensitive - avoid increases in PVR

complications.management: Reduced insufflation pressure to 8mmHg, increased FiO2 to 0.4
Increased respiratory rate, accepted lower SpO2 of 82%

physiologicEffects: Decreased venous return → critical in Fontan
modifications: Higher minute ventilation for CO2 clearance
Consider open technique if hemodynamically unstable

clinicalPearls: Fontan patients have NO physiologic reserve - small changes cause decompensation
Maintain spontaneous ventilation until IV access secured (IM ketamine ideal)
Avoid air bubbles in IV lines - R→L shunt through fenestration
Keep well hydrated - dehydration devastates Fontan circulation
Early extubation preferred - positive pressure impairs Fontan flow
Have milrinone/epinephrine ready for low cardiac output
Avoid high PEEP and mean airway pressures
NPO times should be minimized to prevent dehydration
Consider NIRS monitoring for cerebral/somatic perfusion
Fenestration allows R→L shunt - expect lower SpO2 with increased PVR
keyTakeaways: Fontan circulation = systemic venous pressure dependent
Everything that increases PVR is catastrophic
Laparoscopy particularly challenging in Fontan patients
Early conversion to open if hemodynamic instability
Multidisciplinary approach with pediatric cardiology essential
consultations: Pediatric cardiology - preop echo, available for emergency
wouldDoAgain: Caudal provided excellent analgesia, avoided opioids
wouldChangePerspective: Consider arterial line for beat-to-beat monitoring. Would advocate for open appendectomy from start given Fontan physiology. Consider starting milrinone prophylactically.

physiologyReview: Series circulation: SVC/IVC → Fontan → PAs → PVs → Single ventricle → Aorta
anestheticGoals: Minimize PVR (avoid hypoxia, hypercarbia, acidosis, cold)
emergencyPlanning: Low CO: Volume, reduce PVR (milrinone, NO), inotropes

references: Laparoscopy in single ventricle - Pediatric Anesthesia 2021

comorbidities: Prior CVA with residual left weakness
Non-healing right foot ulcer with osteomyelitis

procedure.name: Right Femoral-Posterior Tibial Bypass with GSV

anesthetic.technique: combined general + lumbar plexus + sciatic blocks
anesthetic.emergence: Remained intubated due to hemodynamic instability

stSegmentChanges.management: Increased nitroglycerin, heparin bolus, optimize HR/BP

complications.management: Heparin infusion, cardiology consult, beta blockade, high-dose statin
Fasciotomy deferred, limb elevation, monitoring compartment pressures
Fluid optimization, avoided nephrotoxins, nephrology consult
complications.outcome: Creatinine 3.8 → 2.9 by POD 5, no dialysis needed

complications.management: Minimize sedation, early mobilization, avoid benzos

clinicalPearls: RCRI score >3 = very high risk, consider cardiology involvement
Continue aspirin perioperatively for vascular surgery
Peripheral blocks reduce cardiac stress vs neuraxial
Dexmedetomidine provides analgesia without respiratory depression in CHF
Tight glucose control may worsen outcomes in acute MI
Consider invasive monitoring early in high-risk patients
Heparin dosing reduced with renal dysfunction
Watch for compartment syndrome after revascularization
These patients often have silent ischemia - monitor ECG closely
Balance: need anticoagulation for graft but bleeding risk
keyTakeaways: Medical optimization often impossible in urgent limb salvage
Peripheral nerve blocks excellent for vascular patients
Perioperative MI common (5-15%) in major vascular surgery
Type 2 MI from supply-demand mismatch most common
Early postop mobilization crucial despite cardiac event

anticoagulation.intraop: Heparin with reduced dose for CKD

cardiacBiomarkers.ekgChanges: ST depression V3-V5, T wave inversions
cardiacBiomarkers.echo: New regional wall motion abnormality, EF 25%

postoperativeManagement.disposition: CCU for cardiac monitoring x48hr → floor

wouldDoAgain: Peripheral blocks worked excellently, avoided neuraxial in patient on dual antiplatelet
wouldChangePerspective: Should have placed arterial line pre-induction. Consider starting milrinone earlier for combined inotropy and afterload reduction. Would involve palliative care earlier given multiple comorbidities.

ethicalConsiderations.goalsOfCare: Discussed preop - wanted limb salvage despite risks
ethicalConsiderations.futility: Not futile - reasonable chance of success despite comorbidities

comorbidities: Right arm and bilateral lower extremity burns

inhalationInjury.bronchoscopyFindings: Severe mucosal edema, carbonaceous debris, erythema to carina

procedure.name: Escharotomy chest/extremities + Bronchoscopy + Central line placement

anesthetic.airway: Awake fiberoptic intubation → ETT 8.0 secured with ties

airwayManagement.securing: Tied with umbilical tape - no adhesive on burns

fluidResuscitation.complications: Abdominal compartment syndrome risk - bladder pressure 22mmHg

temperatureManagement.warmingDevices: Bair hugger, fluid warmer, overhead warmers

complications.management: High peak pressures improved after escharotomy
complications.outcome: Peak pressures decreased from 45 to 28 cmH2O

complications.management: Multimodal with ketamine, regional blocks for extremities planned

clinicalPearls: Airway edema peaks at 24-48 hours - intubate early if any concern
Succinylcholine safe <48hr, contraindicated after (K+ release from extrajunctional receptors)
Fluid requirements often exceed Parkland formula - use clinical endpoints
Vitamin C infusion reduces fluid requirements and edema
Escharotomy dramatically improves chest compliance
CO poisoning + cyanide common in house fires
Ketamine ideal - analgesia, maintains BP, anti-hyperalgesia
Secure ETT with ties, not tape - facial burns will weep
Keep OR hot (>28°C) - hypothermia worsens outcomes
Pain management will be challenging throughout admission
keyTakeaways: Early intubation before edema makes it impossible
Fluid resuscitation guided by endpoints, not formulas
Expect massive fluid shifts and hemodynamic instability
Multimodal analgesia essential from day 1
These patients require multiple surgeries over weeks

ventilation.day3: Pressure control due to decreased compliance

wouldDoAgain: Awake fiberoptic intubation essential - saved his life
wouldChangePerspective: Start vitamin C earlier and higher dose. Consider ECMO early for severe ARDS. Would place femoral lines initially to preserve upper extremity sites for later. Earlier psychology involvement.

procedure.name: Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Thymectomy
procedure.position: Supine with arms tucked → 30° reverse Trendelenburg

anesthetic.emergence: Deep extubation to avoid coughing, then awake

monitoring.clinicalAssessment: Head lift, grip strength, NIF pre/post

complications.presentation: Dyspnea, weak cough, NIF -18, paradoxical breathing
complications.management: BiPAP initially, then intubation, pyridostigmine IV, high-dose steroids
Deepened sevoflurane to 4%, successful second attempt

clinicalPearls: Preop plasmapheresis optimizes strength for surgery
Avoid muscle relaxants if possible - unpredictable response
If relaxant necessary: 1/10th dose rocuronium with sugammadex available
Continue half-dose pyridostigmine morning of surgery
Volatile anesthetics provide muscle relaxation at high concentrations
Avoid drugs that worsen MG: aminoglycosides, Mg, certain antibiotics
Extubation criteria stricter: NIF < -30, sustained head lift >5 sec
Have BiPAP ready in PACU - bridge to avoid reintubation
Postop weakness peaks 24-48 hours after surgery
Regional preferable when possible but not for thymectomy
keyTakeaways: Thymectomy can trigger myasthenic crisis despite optimization
No relaxant technique feasible with adequate depth
Early BiPAP may prevent intubation
ICU monitoring essential first 48-72 hours
Improvement from thymectomy takes months to years

differentiation.myasthenicCrisis: Too little ACh - weakness, responds to pyridostigmine
differentiation.cholinergicCrisis: Too much ACh - fasciculations, miosis, bronchorrhea
differentiation.test: Edrophonium 2mg test dose - improves myasthenic, worsens cholinergic

weaningProtocol.method: SBT with PSV, then CPAP trial

consideredButNotUsed.reason: DLT placement difficult with epidural alone
Avoided due to prior crisis history

educationalValue.simulationScenario: Excellent for crisis resource management training

lessonsLearned: Earlier BiPAP might have prevented reintubation
Consider ICU admission directly from OR
Preop NIF/FVC day of surgery for baseline
qualityImprovement.protocolDevelopment: Created MG perioperative pathway after case

wouldDoAgain: Avoid relaxants strategy worked well intraoperatively
wouldChangePerspective: Would keep intubated overnight given prior crisis history. Consider TIVA instead of volatile to avoid any muscle weakness. Would obtain baseline TOF before induction even without relaxant use.

roboticDetails.complications: Robotic arm collision with anesthesia equipment

precautions: Arms tucked with draw sheet technique
complications: Right arm pressure point despite padding

complications.management: Decreased insufflation to 12mmHg, increased minute ventilation
Head up immediately, delayed extubation, leak test, dexamethasone

clinicalPearls: Steep Trendelenburg + pneumoperitoneum = extreme physiology
Facial edema severe enough to prevent extubation is common
Check eyes/face whenever robot undocked (q30-60min impossible)
IOP can double - avoid in severe glaucoma
Sliding cephalad is dangerous - proper positioning critical
Shoulder braces banned - high brachial plexus injury risk
Laryngeal edema from venous congestion - do leak test
Consider arterial line for long cases in Trendelenburg
Limit fluids - worsens edema, cardiac stress
Latex-free environment essential with robot
keyTakeaways: Position-related complications more common than surgical
5+ hours in steep Trendelenburg causes significant morbidity
Must be prepared for difficult extubation from edema
Nerve injuries common despite careful positioning
Robot limits access - must anticipate problems

emergencyProtocol: 2. Surgeon moves instruments to safe position

ocular.complications: Corneal abrasion, acute glaucoma, ischemic optic neuropathy
ocular.prevention: Tape eyes, check q30min, avoid direct pressure

respiratory.aspiration: Risk with reflux despite ETT cuff

postoperativeManagement.delays: PACU stay extended 2 hours for edema resolution

wouldDoAgain: TAP blocks reduced opioid needs significantly
wouldChangePerspective: Would place arterial line for 5+ hour robotic case. Consider staging - undock and level patient every 2 hours. Would give steroids earlier and higher dose for edema. Consider TIVA to reduce IOP effects.

physiology: Cardiac output decreases despite increased preload

familyHistory.relevant: Cousin had 'bad reaction' to anesthesia - details unknown
familyHistory.unexplainedDeaths: Grandmother died during gallbladder surgery in 1970s
familyHistory.previousAnesthetics: Patient - none; Father - uncomplicated hernia repair

procedure.name: Arthroscopic ACL Reconstruction with Hamstring Autograft
procedure.position: Supine with operative leg in holder

immediateActions.action: First dantrolene dose mixed and given

methods: Ice packs to groin, axilla, neck

complications.management: Serial compartment pressure checks, CK monitoring

clinicalPearls: Unexplained tachycardia + rising ETCO2 = MH until proven otherwise
Masseter spasm after succinylcholine is early warning sign
Temperature is LATE sign - don't wait for fever
Hypercarbia is most sensitive early sign
Machine must be changed or charcoal filters used x48hr
Dantrolene new formulation (Ryanodex) easier to mix - 250mg in 5mL
Give dantrolene until symptoms resolve, no maximum dose
Avoid calcium channel blockers - interact with dantrolene
Call MH hotline early: 1-800-MH-HYPER (1-800-644-9737)
Recrudescence can occur up to 48 hours
keyTakeaways: Early recognition saves lives - mortality now <5%
Don't rationalize early signs - maintain high suspicion
Team response critical - assign roles immediately
Continue dantrolene x48-72 hours to prevent recrudescence
Counsel family - 50% inheritance to children

systemImprovements: MH cart relocated closer to ORs
Cognitive aid cards placed in all ORs

wouldDoAgain: Recognition and treatment protocols worked perfectly
wouldChangePerspective: Should have paid more attention to vague family history of anesthesia problems. Would now specifically ask about MH, unexplained deaths, or ICU admissions after surgery in family. Consider genetic testing before elective surgery in suspicious cases.

procedure.name: Bilateral Intercostal Nerve Blocks T8-T12 for Post-Herpetic Neuralgia

contributingFactors: Possible intravascular injection despite negative aspiration

complications.management: Limited propofol dose, monitored CK, triglycerides

clinicalPearls: CNS symptoms (tinnitus, metallic taste) precede cardiac toxicity
Seizures may be first sign if rapid absorption
Bupivacaine causes refractory cardiac arrest - ratio of CNS:CV toxicity 7:1
Lipid emulsion is lifesaving - don't delay
Maximum recommended dose bupivacaine: 2mg/kg (116mg in this patient)
Continue CPR longer than usual ACLS - may take 30-60 minutes
Reduce epinephrine dose - impairs resuscitation in LAST
Avoid vasopressin, calcium channel blockers, beta blockers
Propofol can interfere with lipid rescue - use different sedation
Send blood for local anesthetic level BEFORE giving lipid
keyTakeaways: Calculate maximum doses BEFORE starting blocks
Use lowest effective concentration
Incremental injection with frequent aspiration
Have lipid emulsion immediately available
Recognition of early symptoms saves lives
Don't exceed 12 mL/kg total lipid dose

theories: Lipid sink - draws LA away from tissues
lipidEmulsionMechanism.pharmacokinetics: Creates expanded lipid phase pulling bupivacaine from cardiac tissue

differentialDiagnosis.keyDistinguishing: Timing after LA injection + prodromal symptoms

outcome.painOutcome: Partial relief achieved with subsequent treatments

followUp.painManagement: Switched to spinal cord stimulator trial

immediateChanges: Lipid emulsion moved to block room
systemChanges: Mandatory timeout for LA dose calculation
qualityImprovement.reporting: FDA MedWatch, ASRA registry, M&M conference

toxicDoses.bupivacaine: 2 mg/kg without epi, 3 mg/kg with epi
toxicDoses.ropivacaine: 3 mg/kg without epi, 4 mg/kg with epi
toxicDoses.lidocaine: 4.5 mg/kg without epi, 7 mg/kg with epi

wouldDoAgain: Lipid rescue protocol executed perfectly - saved patient's life
wouldChangePerspective: Would use 0.25% bupivacaine instead of 0.5%, limit to fewer levels initially, use ropivacaine for lower cardiotoxicity. Should have calculated maximum dose before starting and used test dose.

airwayAssessment.plan: Awake fiberoptic considered but patient refused, opted for RSI with backup plans

timeline.details: Grade 4 view, unable to pass bougie
Despite OPA, two-person technique, no chest rise

timeline.event: Second intubation attempt with video laryngoscope - failed

timeline.details: LMA seated but no ventilation achieved

procedure: Cuff inflated, position confirmed with ETCO2
complications: Moderate bleeding from anterior jugular vein

medications.name: Sugammadex
medications.indication: Ready but not given - airway secured

communication: Help called after first failed intubation
ENT called immediately when CICO recognized
equipmentAvailable: Fiberoptic scope available but not time
Jet ventilation available but not used

postCrisisManagement.surgical: Appendectomy deferred, bedside drainage of abscess

clinicalPearls: Call for help EARLY - after first failed attempt
Declare CICO loudly and clearly to mobilize team
Don't delay cricothyrotomy - brain damage occurs at 3-4 minutes
Scalpel-bougie-tube faster than kit techniques
Horizontal incision in obese patients for landmarks
Confirm with ETCO2, not just breath sounds
Sugammadex won't help if can't oxygenate
Practice cricothyrotomy on simulators regularly
Consider awake intubation in predicted difficult airways
Two-person mask ventilation should be default in obesity
keyTakeaways: CICO is time-critical - every second counts
Multiple attempts worsen edema and bleeding
Cricothyrotomy is lifesaving - must be competent
Team communication crucial during crisis
Debrief thoroughly after critical events

vortexApproach.triggerForCrico: SpO2 <70% with falling despite maximum efforts

difficultAirwayAlgorithm.followed: Modified - progressed rapidly due to desaturation

outcome.psychologicalImpact: PTSD in patient and primary anesthesiologist

legalConsiderations.standardOfCare: Met - appropriate progression to surgical airway
legalConsiderations.disclosure: Full disclosure to patient and family

psychologicalSupport.team: Debriefing session held at 24 hours and 1 week

alternativeApproaches.optimalPlan: Should have insisted on awake intubation

wouldDoAgain: Appropriate emergency response once crisis recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Would have been more insistent on awake intubation despite patient preference. Would call for help immediately after seeing Mallampati IV with thick neck. Would have cricothyrotomy kit open and ready before induction.

comorbidities: 10cm right adrenal mass - presumed benign adenoma

missedDiagnosis.workup: Never had 24hr urine metanephrines or plasma catecholamines
missedDiagnosis.imaging: Adrenal mass found incidentally, no biochemical workup

clinicalPearls: Classic triad: Headaches, palpitations, sweating (only 24% have all three)
Consider pheo in young patients with hypertension
NEVER give beta-blockers before alpha blockade (unopposed alpha crisis)
Tumor manipulation can trigger massive catecholamine release
Post-resection hypotension from catecholamine depletion is expected
Magnesium helps with arrhythmias and vasodilation
Need arterial line BEFORE induction in suspected cases
Biochemical diagnosis MUST precede surgery for adrenal masses
10% are malignant, 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal, 10% familial
Mortality 0-3% with proper preparation, up to 50% if undiagnosed
keyTakeaways: Any adrenal mass needs biochemical workup before surgery
Episodic symptoms + hypertension = consider pheochromocytoma
Alpha blockade MUST precede beta blockade
Prepare for extreme hemodynamic swings
Post-resection shock requires aggressive support

betablockade: Never give first - causes unopposed alpha
otherPreparation: High sodium diet to expand volume

retrospectiveRedFlags: Panic attacks with objective findings (BP, HR)

followUp: Screen for other tumors if familial

associatedSyndromes.screening: Patient later found to have SDHB mutation

identified: No protocol for adrenal mass workup
improvements: Mandatory biochemical testing for adrenal masses
Pheochromocytoma on differential for episodic HTN
Anesthesia input for adrenal surgery planning

differentialDiagnosis.distinguishingFeatures: Extreme BP elevation with tumor manipulation

wouldDoAgain: Crisis management was appropriate once recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Should have cancelled case when saw unworked adrenal mass. Any adrenal tumor needs biochemical testing before surgery - no exceptions. Would have recognized classic symptoms if complete history taken. This was preventable with proper preoperative evaluation.

anesthetic.technique: Epidural for labor → GA for emergency cesarean
anesthetic.maintenance: 100% oxygen, minimal agents due to shock

laboratory.special: Fetal squames in maternal blood (not routinely done)

clinicalPearls: AFE is clinical diagnosis - no confirmatory test
High index of suspicion with sudden cardiopulmonary collapse during labor
Risk factors: Advanced maternal age, multiparity, polyhydramnios, tumultuous labor
Perimortem cesarean within 4 minutes improves maternal and fetal survival
DIC is universal - prepare blood products immediately
Consider ECMO early for refractory shock
Mortality approaches 80% but decreasing with aggressive management
Classic triad present in only 30% of cases
Can occur with any procedure disrupting maternal-fetal barrier
Supportive care is mainstay - no specific treatment
keyTakeaways: Think AFE with sudden collapse during labor/delivery
Immediate delivery improves maternal survival
Aggressive resuscitation with blood products essential
Right heart support critical in early phase
Most survivors have good long-term outcomes if survive initial event

differentialDiagnosis.distinguishing: Timing with labor events, rapid DIC development

timeline: OR ready for hysterectomy within 10 minutes

literature.recurrence: Unknown - most don't have more pregnancies
literature.research: AFE registry ongoing for better understanding

wouldDoAgain: Textbook management - rapid cesarean saved both lives
wouldChangePerspective: Would consider prophylactic arterial line in high-risk patients (polyhydramnios, tumultuous labor). Earlier consideration of ECMO. Would have A-line kit immediately available in all labor rooms.

procedure.name: Retrosigmoid Craniotomy for Acoustic Neuroma Resection

invasive: Central line (right IJ with tip at SVC-RA junction)

clinicalPearls: Sitting position has highest VAE risk (up to 76% with sensitive monitoring)
Precordial Doppler most sensitive practical monitor
ETCO2 decrease often first sign visible to anesthesiologist
PFO present in 25% of population - screen before sitting cases
Small VAE common and well-tolerated, massive VAE catastrophic
N2O absolutely contraindicated - expands bubbles
Multi-orifice catheter better for aspiration than single
Durant position may help but don't delay other treatment
Consider prone or park-bench as alternatives
Hyperbaric oxygen for suspected cerebral air embolism
keyTakeaways: VAE is common in sitting position - be prepared
Team communication and immediate response crucial
Flooding field stops further air entry
Aspiration rarely retrieves significant air
Screen for PFO before elective sitting position cases

neurologicOutcome.stroke: Small left MCA territory, mild hand weakness

debriefing.delays: 3-minute delay in position change during CPR
systemIssues: VAE protocol not posted in OR
improvements: Mandatory bubble study for sitting cases
VAE protocol cognitive aid in all neuro ORs
Consider TEE for all sitting cases

prone.disadvantages: Poor surgical access for CPA tumors

literature.mortality: 1% for all VAE, 48% for massive VAE

wouldDoAgain: Team response saved patient's life with good coordination
wouldChangePerspective: Would insist on preoperative bubble study for PFO screening. Would consider TEE despite interference with neuromonitoring. Would have discussed park-bench position as alternative. Earlier position change during resuscitation.

previousAnesthetics: Wisdom teeth extraction age 18 - no issues

diagnostic.skinTesting: Performed at 6 weeks - positive to cefazolin

clinicalPearls: Anaphylaxis under GA masks classic signs - hypotension often first
Bronchospasm + hypotension + no response to usual treatment = suspect anaphylaxis
Cutaneous signs absent in 10-20% of anaphylaxis
EPINEPHRINE is first-line - don't delay, repeat Q1-2 min
IM epinephrine (0.3-0.5mg) if no IV access
Antibiotics are #1 cause of perioperative anaphylaxis (50-70%)
Neuromuscular blockers #2 cause (20%)
Latex anaphylaxis decreasing with powder-free gloves
Biphasic reactions occur in 20% - observe 24 hours
Tryptase peaks at 1-2 hours, draw serial levels
keyTakeaways: High index of suspicion under GA - classic signs masked
Epinephrine early and often - only drug that saves lives
Remove trigger if possible (stop antibiotic infusion)
Massive fluid requirements from capillary leak
Don't give sugammadex in crisis - contains preservative

grades: Grade II: Measurable but not life-threatening

igeMediatedTypeI.mechanism: Cross-linking of IgE on mast cells

effects.capillaryLeak: Up to 35% blood volume in 10 minutes

wouldDoAgain: Excellent crisis management once recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Should have recognized anaphylaxis earlier - bronchospasm plus hypotension should trigger immediate epinephrine. Would give test dose of antibiotic and wait 5 minutes. Would have epinephrine drawn up prophylactically in atopic patient.

comorbidities: Traumatic brain injury - mild, 2 years ago

procedure.name: Open Reduction Internal Fixation Tibial Plateau Fracture

anesthetic.technique: general with femoral and sciatic blocks

missed: No preoperative discussion of PTSD triggers

neurologic: Limbic system activation before prefrontal cortex

clinicalPearls: Emergence delirium ≠ emergence agitation - different entities
Young males highest risk (10-15% incidence)
PTSD/TBI significantly increase risk
Sevoflurane > desflurane > isoflurane for ED risk
Physical restraint can escalate - chemical restraint safer
Staff safety paramount - back away if violent
Most episodes self-limited (5-15 minutes)
Ketamine excellent for severe agitation
Document as critical incident for workers comp
Consider substance withdrawal as contributor
keyTakeaways: Prevention better than treatment
PTSD patients need special emergence planning
Call for help early - don't try to manage alone
Protect staff - violence is real risk
Chemical >>> physical restraint
wouldDoAgain: Code gray activation was appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have recognized PTSD as major risk and used TIVA with dexmedetomidine throughout. Would have had ketamine drawn up prophylactically. Should have discussed emergence concerns with patient preoperatively and had support person available. Would avoid sevoflurane in PTSD patient.

transfusionHistory.previous: 2 units during breast surgery 8 years ago

anesthetic.extubation: Awake in OR → Reintubated in PACU

traliDefinition: Acute onset within 6 hours of transfusion ✓

process: Anti-HLA or anti-HNA antibodies in donor plasma
Neutrophil activation and sequestration in lungs

imaging.cxr: Bilateral diffuse infiltrates, normal heart size
imaging.echo: Normal EF, no LV dysfunction, PCWP normal

specialTests.hla_antibodies: Donor positive for anti-HLA Class II

distinguishingFeatures.taco: Would have elevated BNP, CVP, respond to diuretics

clinicalPearls: TRALI is leading cause of transfusion mortality
Onset within 6 hours of transfusion (usually 1-2 hours)
All blood products can cause TRALI - plasma products highest risk
Multiparous female donors highest risk (HLA antibodies)
Male-only plasma reduces TRALI incidence by 75%
Diagnosis of exclusion - rule out TACO, aspiration
BNP <100 suggests TRALI over TACO
Treatment is supportive - most recover in 48-96 hours
Mortality 5-10% (better than other ARDS)
Can receive blood products in future (different donors)
keyTakeaways: High index of suspicion with respiratory distress post-transfusion
Stop transfusion immediately
Differentiate from TACO (circulatory overload)
Lung protective ventilation crucial
Report to blood bank for investigation

implemented: Screen female donors for HLA antibodies

immediate: Quarantine all products from implicated donors

wouldDoAgain: Appropriate recognition and management once identified
wouldChangePerspective: FFP given for INR 1.8 was likely unnecessary - should have higher threshold (>2.0) for prophylactic plasma. Would monitor in PACU longer after multiple blood products. Should have lower threshold for ICU admission after significant transfusion.

comorbidities: Recent TIA 3 weeks ago (left arm weakness)
Coronary artery disease - stent 2 years ago
Incomplete Circle of Willis on MRA

neurologicBaseline.deficits: Mild left hand weakness from recent TIA

timeline.monitors: No improvement, now flat EEG left

imaging.ct: No hemorrhage, early ischemic changes right MCA

clinicalPearls: Neuromonitoring changes demand immediate action
Shunt threshold: stump pressure <40-50 mmHg
Time is brain - every minute counts
MAP augmentation may not overcome poor collaterals
Consider regional anesthesia in high-risk patients
Incomplete Circle of Willis increases stroke risk 3-fold
Delayed shunt placement worsens outcomes
Post-CEA stroke often embolic, not hemodynamic
Immediate imaging crucial for intervention options
Thrombectomy possible even hours after onset
keyTakeaways: React immediately to monitoring changes
Shunt early if any concern
Maintain high MAP throughout
Have stroke protocol activated
Time to reperfusion determines outcome
wouldDoAgain: Good monitoring and detection
wouldChangePerspective: Should have placed shunt immediately with first monitoring change - don't wait for multiple confirmations. Would consider awake technique given multiple risk factors. Would have stroke team on standby. Consider hybrid OR for immediate intervention capability.

mechanism: Irrigation fluid absorption via prostatic veins

surgical: Consider staged procedure for large prostates
anesthetic: Spinal to T10 (patient can report symptoms)

clinicalPearls: Classic triad: Hyponatremia, fluid overload, CNS symptoms
Awake patients report symptoms earlier
Bradycardia + hypertension = suspect TURP syndrome
Glycine causes transient blindness via retinal effects
Ammonia from glycine metabolism worsens encephalopathy
Correct sodium slowly except with seizures/coma
3% saline 100mL raises sodium ~1-2 mEq/L
Risk of central pontine myelinolysis with rapid correction
Modern techniques use saline irrigation (bipolar)
Consider alternative procedures for prostates >80g
keyTakeaways: High index of suspicion with neurologic changes
Stop surgery immediately
Severe symptoms need 3% saline
Avoid overcorrection (osmotic demyelination)
Prevention through surgical technique

costAnalysis.prevention: Bipolar TURP or laser would prevent

wouldDoAgain: Appropriate management once recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Should have checked sodium at 60 minutes given large prostate size. Would advocate for bipolar technique or laser for 110g prostate. Should have recognized restlessness and nausea as early signs. Would limit resection time to 60 minutes with staged procedure if needed.

comorbidities: Previous unexplained rash during surgery 10 years ago
previousAnesthetics: D&C 10 years ago - unexplained rash, self-limited
Colonoscopy 2 years ago - MAC, no issues

bloodProducts: Emergency release PRBCs x2 during crisis

clinicalPearls: Anaphylaxis is clinical diagnosis - treat immediately
IM epinephrine works faster than IV for mild-moderate
Sugammadex can cause anaphylaxis independent of NMBA
Rocuronium #1 cause of perioperative anaphylaxis in many countries
Tryptase peaks at 1-2 hours, get serial levels
Biphasic reactions occur in 20% - observe 24 hours
Cross-reactivity common among aminosteroid NMBAs
Latex allergy decreasing, NMBA allergy increasing
Don't delay epinephrine - no absolute contraindications
Steroids don't help acute phase but may prevent biphasic
keyTakeaways: Epinephrine is first-line - don't delay
IM faster than IV for initial dose if not arrested
Serial tryptase levels confirm diagnosis
Observe 24 hours for biphasic reaction
Refer for allergy testing postoperatively
wouldDoAgain: Rapid recognition and epinephrine administration appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Given history of unexplained rash during prior surgery, should have considered preoperative allergy consultation and testing. Would have epinephrine drawn up prophylactically. Should have given IM epinephrine immediately when hypotension + rash occurred rather than trying IV route first. Would avoid sugammadex given increasing reports of anaphylaxis.

obstetricHistory.presentingComplaint: Labor pains, extreme shortness of breath

procedure.name: Emergency Cesarean for Non-reassuring Fetal Status

physical.cardiac: S3 gallop, JVD to angle of jaw

diagnosticCriteria: Heart failure in last month of pregnancy or within 5 months postpartum

clinicalPearls: PPCM can present as 'asthma' or pneumonia in pregnancy
Mortality 10-20% despite treatment
50% recover EF completely by 6 months
Bromocriptine may improve recovery (blocks prolactin)
Future pregnancy contraindicated if EF <50%
Can progress to needing VAD or transplant
BNP >100 pg/mL abnormal in pregnancy
Regional preferred but watch preload dependence
Avoid methylergonovine - increases afterload
Consider early delivery if deteriorating
keyTakeaways: High suspicion in peripartum dyspnea
Bedside echo is diagnostic
Aggressive heart failure management
Consider mechanical support early
Multidisciplinary team essential

bromocriptineProtocol.dosing: 2.5mg BID x 2 weeks, then daily x 4 weeks

wouldDoAgain: Rapid diagnosis and aggressive management appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have obtained echo when patient reported progressive dyspnea and orthopnea during prenatal visit. Multiple risk factors (twins, African American, gestational HTN) should have triggered screening. Would start bromocriptine immediately after diagnosis. Should have had mechanical support team on standby given EF 20%.

preoperativeWorkup.echo: Normal, bubble study negative for PFO

procedure.name: Posterior Fossa Craniotomy for Acoustic Neuroma

mechanism: Pressure gradient (negative venous pressure in sitting position)
Height difference creates 2mmHg gradient per inch

immediate: Notify surgeon - flood field with saline

diagnosis.imaging: MRI shows air in MCA territory

clinicalPearls: VAE can occur in any surgery where veins are above heart
Lethal dose: 3-5 mL/kg (200-300mL in adult)
Doppler detects before hemodynamic changes
Mill-wheel murmur is late/ominous sign
ETN2 most specific monitor (air contains 78% N2)
Durant position helps trap air in RV apex
Can aspirate 50% of entrained air via CVP
Paradoxical embolism occurs in 10-25% of VAE
PFO present in 25% of population
HBO therapy within 6 hours for arterial air
keyTakeaways: Sitting position highest risk but VAE possible in any position
Multi-modal monitoring essential
Immediate recognition and treatment crucial
Team communication critical
Consider avoiding sitting position if PFO

issues: Echo without bubble study missed PFO
improvements: Mandatory bubble study for sitting cases

wouldDoAgain: Rapid recognition and management appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have insisted on bubble study preoperatively given sitting position planned - negative TTE doesn't rule out PFO. Would advocate for prone or lateral position. Should have maintained higher CVP (8-10) throughout. Would have HBO team on standby for sitting position cases.

mechanicalTheory: Fat globules from marrow enter venous system
Some pass through lungs or PFO → systemic
biochemicalTheory: Fat globules broken down by lipases
Free fatty acids cause endothelial damage

prophylaxis.timing: Within 12 hours of injury if used

clinicalPearls: Classic triad present in only 10-40% of cases
Petechial rash pathognomonic but only 60% have it
Look in axillae, chest, conjunctiva for petechiae
Occurs 12-72 hours after long bone fracture
Young patients with multiple fractures highest risk
Intramedullary nailing increases risk vs external fixation
MRI brain shows characteristic 'starfield' pattern
Mortality 10-20% in severe cases
Most survivors have good long-term outcome
Prevention better than treatment
keyTakeaways: High suspicion with long bone fractures
Respiratory symptoms often first
Petechiae are pathognomonic when present
Supportive care is mainstay
Early recognition improves outcomes

specific: TEE can show fat in transit

evidenceBased: External fixation initially for damage control

wouldDoAgain: Appropriate supportive care provided
wouldChangePerspective: Should have considered staged fixation with external fixation first given multiple long bone fractures. Would give prophylactic steroids earlier (within 12 hours). Should have maintained higher suspicion when SpO2 dropped during reaming. Daily fundoscopic exams from POD 0.

procedure.name: L2-S1 Posterior Spinal Fusion with Instrumentation

complications: Unable to check eyes after draping

timeline.examination: Pupils reactive, fundi difficult to see

fundoscopy.acute: Disc edema, no cherry red spot

imaging.oct: Retinal nerve fiber layer edema then loss

types.crao: Central retinal artery occlusion - direct pressure

positioning: Head above heart level (10° reverse Trendelenburg)
Avoid direct eye pressure - check frequently
monitoring: Document eye checks q2hr if possible

clinicalPearls: POVL incidence 0.03-0.2% but devastating
PION more common than CRAO in spine surgery
Risk increases dramatically after 6 hours
No proven treatment - prevention crucial
Vision loss often bilateral with PION
May not be recognized until POD 1-7
Direct eye pressure causes CRAO (cherry red spot)
PION has no cherry red spot
Males 2x risk of females
Recovery extremely rare
keyTakeaways: High-risk patient should have been identified
Staged procedure should be considered >6 hours
Head position critical - keep above heart
Avoid hypotension AND anemia together
Check vision immediately postop in high-risk

alternatives.staged: Could have done L2-4 then L4-S1
alternatives.awake: Regional with sedation for some cases

wouldDoAgain: Recognition and consultation appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: This case should have been staged given duration >6 hours predicted and multiple risk factors. Head should have been positioned above heart level. Would maintain MAP >70 and Hgb >9 throughout. Would check vision immediately in PACU. Should have discussed POVL risk specifically in consent.

comorbidities: Previous intubation at age 4 for status asthmaticus

anesthetic.extubation: Deep extubation in OR after resolution

clinicalPearls: Silent chest = life-threatening bronchospasm
Can't ventilate + high pressure = bronchospasm until proven otherwise
Shark fin capnography pathognomonic
Deepen before treating if possible
IM epinephrine works when IV drugs can't reach lungs
Ketamine excellent for bronchospasm
Auto-PEEP causes hypotension (decreased venous return)
Allow complete exhalation - may need to disconnect circuit
Peak pressure misleading - plateau pressure more useful
Consider pneumothorax if sudden deterioration
keyTakeaways: Recent URI increases risk 7-fold
Don't hesitate with IM epinephrine for severe bronchospasm
Multiple simultaneous therapies needed
Permissive hypercapnia acceptable
Surgery should be cancelled after severe bronchospasm

improvements: Should have postponed with recent URI

wouldDoAgain: Aggressive management appropriate once occurred
wouldChangePerspective: Should have postponed elective surgery with recent URI in asthmatic child - guidelines suggest 4-6 weeks. Would pretreat with prednisone if proceeding. Would maintain deeper anesthesia before any airway manipulation. Would have IM epinephrine drawn up prophylactically in severe asthmatics.

medications: Linezolid 600mg BID x5 days (for MRSA UTI)

psychiatricHistory.recentChanges: Linezolid started 5 days ago by PCP

chlorpromazine.dose: Not given - avoided due to hyperthermia

distinguishing.ss_vs_mh: Onset timing, trigger agents, clonus present
distinguishing.ss_vs_nms: Hyperreflexia vs rigidity, onset hours vs days

complications.outcome: CK peaked at 8,500, no dialysis needed

clinicalPearls: Clonus (especially ocular) is most specific finding
Legs > arms hyperreflexia typical
Linezolid is an MAO inhibitor - often forgotten
Hunter criteria more sensitive than Sternbach
Onset usually within 24 hours of trigger
Cyproheptadine is specific antidote
Avoid physical restraints - worsen hyperthermia
Most cases resolve in 24 hours with treatment
Don't confuse with MH - different treatment
Tramadol is high-risk drug for SS
keyTakeaways: Review ALL medications for serotonergic activity
Linezolid + antidepressants = dangerous
Clonus + hyperreflexia = serotonin syndrome
Stop offending agents immediately
Cyproheptadine is specific treatment
wouldDoAgain: Recognition and treatment appropriate once identified
wouldChangePerspective: Should have recognized drug interaction preoperatively - linezolid + multiple serotonergic drugs is contraindicated. Would have delayed surgery for medication washout. Should have recognized early signs (tremor, anxiety, mild hyperthermia) as possible serotonin syndrome. Complete medication reconciliation essential.

comorbidities: Metastatic carcinoid tumor - small bowel primary
Right heart failure - TR, TV disease

procedure.name: Hepatic Artery Embolization for Liver Metastases

clinicalPearls: Carcinoid crisis can be life-threatening
Octreotide is first-line treatment - large doses needed
Avoid histamine-releasing drugs
Paradoxical hypertension can occur
Catecholamines may worsen crisis initially
Vasopressin preferred for hypotension
Right heart failure common - check echo
Bronchospasm treat with anticholinergics first
Crisis can last hours despite treatment
Postop octreotide infusion often needed
keyTakeaways: High-dose octreotide preop essential
Have octreotide infusion ready
Avoid triggers and histamine-releasers
Expect hemodynamic instability
Multidisciplinary planning crucial

preop.echo: Moderate TR, mild PR, RV dysfunction

wouldDoAgain: Appropriate crisis management with octreotide
wouldChangePerspective: Would start octreotide infusion prophylactically before procedure given high tumor burden. Should have used higher preop dose (500mcg vs 100mcg). Would avoid phenylephrine initially - vasopressin better choice. Consider staging embolization to reduce mediator release.

procedure.name: Emergency Cesarean Section for Fetal Distress

bronchoscopy.findings: Food particles to subsegmental bronchi bilaterally

ventilation: Pressure control due to poor compliance

clinicalPearls: Aspiration is clinical diagnosis - witnessed or high suspicion
Immediate bronchoscopy for particulate matter only
Antibiotics NOT indicated initially (chemical pneumonitis)
Steroids do NOT improve outcomes
ARDS develops in 30% of aspiration cases
Mortality 30-40% if ARDS develops
Pregnant patients highest risk - delayed gastric emptying
pH <2.5 and volume >25mL (0.4mL/kg) increase severity
Bacterial superinfection common after 48-72 hours
ECMO reasonable for young patients with reversible disease
keyTakeaways: Failed regional → RSI without delay
Obesity + pregnancy + GERD = extreme risk
Aspiration can occur despite cricoid pressure
Lung protective ventilation crucial
Consider ECMO early in young patients

improvements: Consider awake intubation in extreme obesity

wouldDoAgain: Immediate bronchoscopy and ARDS management appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have proceeded directly to awake intubation given extreme aspiration risk (BMI 52, pregnancy, GERD, gastroparesis). Time wasted on spinal attempts with worsening fetal status forced emergency conditions. Would place OG tube immediately after intubation. Earlier ECMO consultation when P/F <100.

timeline.decision: Too late for tPA (>4.5hr from possible onset)

clinicalPearls: Delayed emergence requires systematic evaluation
Anisocoria suggests structural lesion
Decerebrate posturing indicates brainstem injury
Basilar occlusion can present as coma
Posterior circulation strokes often missed
Time of onset uncertain under anesthesia
Permissive HTN crucial in acute stroke
Thrombectomy possible up to 24 hours in selected cases
Afib + held anticoagulation = high risk
Brief hypotension can precipitate watershed infarcts
keyTakeaways: Not all delayed emergence is residual anesthetic
Neurologic exam crucial when emergence delayed
Low threshold for imaging with focal findings
Stroke can occur intraoperatively
Time is brain - rapid evaluation essential

pharmacologic: Opioid excess - no response to naloxone

wouldDoAgain: Rapid recognition and thrombectomy appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have considered bridging anticoagulation given CHA2DS2-VASc of 4 and prior TIA. Would maintain higher blood pressure intraoperatively. Should have immediately performed neurologic exam when patient didn't emerge at MAC 0.2. CT should have been obtained within 20 minutes of failed emergence with focal findings.

medications: Recently stopped medications 1 week ago (couldn't afford)

thyroidHistory.lastTSH: Unknown - hasn't seen endocrinologist in 6 months

clinicalPearls: Thyroid storm mortality 10-30% with treatment, 80-90% without
Must give PTU before iodine (blocks organification)
Propranolol preferred - blocks T4→T3 conversion
Never use aspirin - increases free hormone
Steroids essential - blocks conversion + relative insufficiency
Temperature may not correlate with severity
High-output failure common despite tachycardia
Burch-Wartofsky score >45 suggests storm
Can occur in subclinical hyperthyroidism
Post-treatment hypothyroidism common
keyTakeaways: Recognize hyperthyroid patients preop
Postpone elective surgery if possible
Beta-blockade essential perioperatively
Have storm protocol ready
Multi-step treatment approach critical
wouldDoAgain: Rapid recognition and treatment appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have delayed surgery for optimization given positive Murphy's sign but stable vitals - could have treated with antibiotics first. Should have recognized severe hyperthyroidism preop (TSH <0.01, tremor, tachycardia) and involved endocrinology. Would give higher dose steroids and start PTU immediately in holding area.

medications: Prednisone 10mg daily x 8 years (recently tapered from 20mg)
Last prednisone dose: 2 days ago (stopped for 'surgery')

preoperativeAssessment.missed: No one recognized chronic steroid use implications

triggeringFactors: Chronic steroid suppression of HPA axis

hpaAxis.suppressed: Chronic steroids → ACTH suppression → Adrenal atrophy
hpaAxis.recovery: Can take 6-12 months after stopping steroids

definitive.interpretation: Central adrenal insufficiency from chronic steroids

clinicalPearls: Any steroid use >5mg x 3 weeks suppresses HPA axis
Suppression can last 6-12 months after stopping
Cushingoid appearance = suppressed axis
Hypotension + hypoglycemia + hyponatremia = adrenal crisis
Hydrocortisone preferred (has mineralocorticoid activity)
Don't delay treatment for testing
Vasopressors work poorly without steroids
Perioperative coverage prevents crisis
Topical/inhaled steroids can suppress axis
Etomidate can precipitate crisis (inhibits synthesis)
keyTakeaways: Never stop chronic steroids abruptly
Stress-dose steroids for surgery
High index of suspicion saves lives
Refractory hypotension think adrenal
Treatment before testing

identified: Preop assessment missed steroid history significance
Patient told to stop all medications
improvements: EMR alerts for chronic steroid users

wouldDoAgain: Immediate hydrocortisone once recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Should have recognized chronic steroid use preoperatively and given stress-dose steroids before induction. Never should have told patient to stop prednisone. Would give 100mg hydrocortisone with induction for anyone on chronic steroids. Recognition was delayed - refractory hypotension with hypoglycemia should trigger immediate consideration.

recentHistory.diarrhea: Resolved, but still having loose stools

regionalBlock.topical: EMLA cream applied preop by parents

mechanism: Oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ in hemoglobin

pulseOximetry.limitation: Reads MetHb as mixture of oxy/deoxy

methyleneBlue.repeat: May repeat in 1 hour if needed

clinicalPearls: Infants <6 months highest risk (reduced MetHb reductase)
Benzocaine most common cause in pediatrics
SpO2 plateaus at 85% regardless of MetHb level
Chocolate brown blood is pathognomonic
Saturation gap (calculated vs measured) is diagnostic
PaO2 normal on ABG despite cyanosis
Methylene blue works within 30 minutes
Can turn urine blue-green (warn parents)
G6PD deficiency contraindicates methylene blue
Multiple sources can be additive
keyTakeaways: High suspicion with unexplained desaturation
Check for benzocaine/prilocaine exposure
Co-oximetry is diagnostic
Methylene blue is treatment
Infants are high risk

screening: Check for G6PD if high risk

saturationType.pulseOx: Reads MetHb as 85% regardless of level

reporting.changes: Benzocaine removed from formulary for <2 years

literature.incidence: Rare but increasing with OTC products

wouldDoAgain: Rapid diagnosis and treatment with methylene blue appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have obtained detailed history about OTC products including teething gels preoperatively. Would avoid EMLA in infant <6 months having penile block. Should limit total local anesthetic exposure. Would have co-oximetry immediately available for infants receiving prilocaine. Parents should be educated about benzocaine risks.

citrateToxicity.mechanism: Citrate in blood products chelates calcium

clinicalPearls: Activate MTP early - don't wait for lab values
1:1:1 ratio improves survival
Warm all products to prevent hypothermia
Calcium required after 4-6 units
Citrate toxicity presents as hypotension + prolonged QT
TACO more common than TRALI (1:100 vs 1:5000)
TXA reduces mortality if given early
Fibrinogen first coagulation factor to fall
Avoid crystalloid once MTP activated
Consider whole blood if available
keyTakeaways: Early MTP activation saves lives
Balanced resuscitation prevents coagulopathy
Monitor and treat hypocalcemia
Maintain normothermia
Team communication essential
wouldDoAgain: Appropriate MTP activation and balanced resuscitation
wouldChangePerspective: Should have started calcium replacement earlier - after 4 units rather than waiting for symptoms. Would pre-warm room and have Level 1 infuser ready from start. Should have used fibrinogen concentrate earlier when level dropped below 150. Would consider cell salvage despite relative contraindication.

clinicalPearls: Succinylcholine contraindicated in neuromuscular disease
Masseter spasm may be first sign
ECG changes precede arrest
Calcium is first-line for cardiac toxicity
Multiple doses of calcium often needed
Hyperventilation provides rapid temporizing
Young males with 'clumsiness' need evaluation
CK should be checked if weakness history
Family history crucial - X-linked pattern
Rhabdomyolysis common after succinylcholine
keyTakeaways: Careful history for weakness/falls
Avoid succinylcholine if any doubt
Recognize peaked T waves immediately
Calcium first, ask questions later
Multiple simultaneous treatments needed
wouldDoAgain: Appropriate hyperkalemia management once recognized
wouldChangePerspective: Should have taken detailed history about exercise tolerance, stair climbing, and family history of early deaths. Physical exam should have included muscle bulk assessment. Would never use succinylcholine in young male without thorough neuromuscular assessment. Should use rocuronium 1.2mg/kg for RSI as default. CK should be checked if any weakness history.

clinicalPearls: Classic triad: Headache, sweating, palpitations
Present in only 40% of cases
Rule of 10s: 10% bilateral, malignant, extra-adrenal, familial, children
Alpha blockade MUST precede beta blockade
Hypertensive crisis + pulmonary edema = think pheo
Plasma metanephrines best screening test
Avoid glucagon, metoclopramide, droperidol
Magnesium helpful for crisis
Genetic testing for all patients
Can present as cardiogenic shock
keyTakeaways: Young + severe HTN = investigate
Never give beta-blockers first
Phentolamine is drug of choice acutely
Surgery requires 2 weeks preparation
40% are hereditary
wouldDoAgain: Recognition and phentolamine administration appropriate
wouldChangePerspective: Should have recognized classic triad preoperatively (headaches, sweating, palpitations) with difficult-to-control hypertension in young patient. Would obtain plasma metanephrines for any young patient with severe or episodic hypertension. Should have investigated previous hypertensive episode during colonoscopy. Family history of sudden death at 48 concerning. Would never proceed with elective surgery without workup.
